pageContext.analysis: This is false. The United States ran trade deficits in goods (Trump's preferred metric) with Mexico five out of the ten years before the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, according to the Census Bureau. In the years when the United States ran a goods surplus, it was never more than $5 billion and usually about $1-2 billion. But what matters is not the deficit or surplus but rather the level of trade between the two countries. Cross border trade in goods was about $100 billion in 1994, compared to more than $500 billion in 2018. According to the Department of Commerce, U.S. exports of Goods and Services to Mexico supported an estimated 1.2 million jobs in 2015 (latest data available).
